Posts.Title: Elbow forearm pain on node/lumpectomy side MzJ MzJ

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 06:03PM MzJ wrote: Hi Leah,  Thank you for replying, I appreciate it!   Yes, the rad nurses told me the same thing today.  They said it would be OK to take antibiotics during treatment.   It's good to know I shouldn't have these headaches forever.
Posts.Title: Constant sinus headache: SE or coincidence? MzJ MzJ

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2010 12:48AM MzJ wrote: Unfortunately I still have the headache.  It's been 16 straight days now. On Wed 3/17 I saw my regular doctor; he gave me an antibiotic and said to stop taking Advil Cold & Sinus and take Mucinex Extra Strength instead. So now I'm taking that andI'm still taking ibuprofen 2 to 3 times a day.   I live in Cleveland and have had sinusitus and seasonal allergy issues all my life.  The thing that I find odd about the past 16 days is how consistent the headache pain has been. Usually for me, ear/nose/throat issues tend to move around between my head,nose,throat & chest.   This time I've got no other symptoms, no runny nose, no scratchy throat, no cough.  Just the headaches.         All the doctors and all the nurses assure me the headaches have nothing to do with the radiation treatment.  I've completed 15 of 30 zappings.  The fatigue is building and I definately blame the headaches for that.
Posts.Title: Constant sinus headache: SE or coincidence? MzJ MzJ

Posts.Content: MzJ wrote: I've had a sinus headache every day since Day 3 of Radiation.  The good news is that Advil Cold & Sinus and ibuprofen take the headache away. But the bad news is,  a few hours later, my head HURTS, right behind my eyes. No sneezing, no congestion; just pain.  It's been like this for 10 straight days now. I'm going to discuss this again with the doctor.   Has anyone here had sinus headaches during radiation treatment? What did you take? I've got 4 weeks of rads to go. I don't think I can keep taking Advil & ibuprofen 3 times a day. What if the headaches don't stop even after rads stop? Is this a permanent side effect?     ~~~positive vibes~~~ Dx 12/15/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Constant sinus headache: SE or coincidence? MzJ MzJ

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 12:18AM MzJ wrote: Hi Estepp,  yes 'tis the season here too. I'm sure the weather is what brought the headaches on, but I fear that radiation is playing a part in why it's so hard to kick.  I think I read it weakens our immune system.  I worry about taking so much Advil and ibuprofen; I bet it's not good for my stomach and I'm building up a tolerance :(
Posts.Title: Constant sinus headache: SE or coincidence? MzJ MzJ

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2010 09:14AM MzJ wrote: My doc offered this analogy comparing cancer to a dandelion/weed in your front lawn...the lumpectomy pulled the weed out.....radiation is like a gardener spritzing the specific spot to make sure any root pieces are killed off to help reduce the chance of the weed coming back.... hormone or chemo therapy is another gardener that walks around with a sprayer treating the whole rest of the lawn, backyard and side, to help further reduce the chance of that weed spreading.
Posts.Title: Why are Tamoxifen and Radiation BOTH necessary (for some women)? Raili idaho

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 01:02AM MzJ wrote: Hello inthepink :)   I sensed the concern in your posts and wanted to extend my support. Yes you will find these boards to be quite a godsend. There are lots of great stories and good information.    Although your surgeon may not have the best bed-side manner, I wanted to mention that (in my opinion) she's doing everything right and steering you in the right direction.  My case is very similar to yours.  During my lumpectomy, a second lump was discovered and removed.  After testing it was determined I needed clearer margins so I needed a 2nd surgery a month later.  It's not the fault of the surgeon or because someone misread the mammogram.  Sometimes it just happens that way, they see stuff better "in person". And I'm glad the good doctor was alert and didn't just stick to the mammogram plan; if she had I would still have the 2nd lump still growing inside me.   I am also HER2-.  I don't think it is your surgeon's bias against chemo....it's that our type of cancer isn't as aggressive as HER2+ and therefore chemo isn't standard treatment for us.       (PS- I completed 6 weeks of radiation. Started Tamoxifen a month ago.  Last week I had my followup mammogram and it went great!)
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 07:10PM MzJ wrote: Hi Susie, I've felt that way many many times.  I've been at the same company for over 20 years and the past 4 years have been bad...stressful, unfair, mis-managed etc.  I'm tired of thinking "it's hit bottom so it's gotta get better" because it's not.    Here's what I do to get through: I search online and try to find a position in my area that offers the insurance, vacation time, benefits & salary that I have now if not better.  Most of the time I can't find one. So then I rationalize that I'm staying where I am because there is no real option.  Hey, I tried! Guess I gotta make do with what I've got.      A few times I have found something that looked promising.  Once I got up enough nerve and submitted a resume. It was so hard not to mention it to co-workers.  I was on pins and needles for days expecting an interview request.  Ego smack!  I never got a reply.    So I say, go ahead and look for a better job. It's empowering to take action, don't feel trapped.   If you find a great job, awesome! Go for it!   But don't leave your current job until you have another one confirmed. That's not being trapped, just being an economical realist.    In the meantime, try to look at work as just work.  Do your best. Then go home and enjoy your family time.
